BIOS222
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments including those characterised by extreme chemical and physical factors such as low or high oxygen levels or temperature. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. Using case studies, the module will explore physiological control systems and phenotypically plastic responses, behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the diversity, time frames and limits of physiological mechanisms that animals employ to survive and thrive in challenging environments.

2. To raise students’ critical awareness of the challenges of interacting abiotic environmental factors encountered by animals in their natural environments.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Outline Syllabus
This module builds on and further develops the principles of species-environmental interactions introduced in Year 1 core modules. There are 4 overarching topics whose concepts are developed over a 1-2 week introduction period and that are exemplified and built upon in 3-4, 2-3-week long detailed case studies

● General principles of species-environmental interactions, including definitions and examples of tolerance ranges, fundamental and realised niche, climate envelopes, and effects of stable to highly variable environments.

● Consideration of general timeframes of both environmental changes and animal responses, including geological/evolutionary to ongoing global environmental change, organismal range shifts, expansions, contractions and extinctions.

● Examples of mechanisms and limits of physiological control systems (conformity, regulation, homeostasis) and comparison or integration with phenotypically plastic responses (physiological/biochemical/morphological plasticity), behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses  

● A detailed examination of environmental challenges to animal life, including physical and chemical factors defining and differentiating ecosystems, e.g. latitude and elevation or water depth, oxygen levels (normoxic, hypoxic, anoxic, or hyperoxic), temperature (minimum, maximum and average), water availability, soil or water chemistry and nutrient content.

● Case studies of mechanisms of environmental adaptation

3-4 case studies including different groups of organisms and environments according to teaching staff expertise. Cross cutting themes include for example:

- Diversity of solutions to similar challenges across organisms, e.g. endotherms versus ectotherms; invertebrates versus vertebrates

- Integration of adaptive mechanisms from cellular to whole organism levels

- Relationships between lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation and ability to maintain homeostasis

- Ecological consequences of adaptive processes
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (2 lectures and 1 workshop in each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (Inclusivity). During workshops, students will be encouraged to discuss relevant topics in small groups (active learning, confidence). Students will be encouraged to reflect on local, national and global phenomena, e.g. in relation to climate change (global citizenship).

Lectures:

These will cover the core module content.

Attendance Record: Yes

Workshops:

Structured workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics through active learning. Workshops will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools such as Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two assignments. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a 5-minute explainer video based on topics from the first half of the module. In this assessment, we expect students to produce an informative and engaging video aimed at first year Biosciences students. When writing the script, students are expected to use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. As a formative task, students will have the opportunity to submit a short (30 sec) video to develop their video making skills. Due to the nature of this task, this assessment is not anonymous.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is a final written exam consisting of short answer questions. The questions consist of problem solving tasks and critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. When they address the question, students should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use their understanding of relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis.
Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. In addition, the video assessment resembles a potential ‘real life’ situation that students may encounter in their professional life. The final exam requires students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Analyse relationships between animal lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation, and ability to maintain homeostasis.
 LO2 Evaluate integrative physiological mechanisms enabling animals to survive in potentially hostile environmental conditions.
 LO3 Critically discuss major transitions in the evolution of animals, e.g. air-breathing, terrestriality, or endothermy.
 LO4 Evaluate and interpret data to solve problems and predict outcomes related to survival of species

- Diversity of solutions to similar challenges across organisms, e.g. endotherms versus ectotherms; invertebrates versus vertebrates

- Relationships between lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation and ability to maintain homeostasis

- Ecological consequences of adaptive processes

Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will be encouraged to reflect on local, national and global phenomena, e.g. in relation to climate change (global citizenship).

Workshops:

Structured workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics through active learning. Workshops will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools such as Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two assignments. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a 5-minute explainer video based on topics from the first half of the module. In this assessment, we expect students to produce an informative and engaging video aimed at first year Biosciences students. When writing the script, students are expected to use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. As a formative task, students will have the opportunity to submit a short (30 sec) video to develop their video making skills. Due to the nature of this task, this assessment is not anonymous.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is a final written exam consisting of short answer questions. The questions consist of problem solving tasks and critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. When they address the question, students should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use their understanding of relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis.
Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. In addition, the video assessment resembles a potential ‘real life’ situation that students may encounter in their professional life. The final exam requires students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS222
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments including those characterised by extreme chemical and physical factors such as low or high oxygen levels or temperature. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. Using case studies, the module will explore physiological control systems and phenotypically plastic responses, behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the diversity, time frames and limits of physiological mechanisms that animals employ to survive and thrive in challenging environments.

2. To raise students’ critical awareness of the challenges of interacting abiotic environmental factors encountered by animals in their natural environments.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Outline Syllabus
This module builds on and further develops the principles of species-environmental interactions introduced in Year 1 core modules. There are 4 overarching topics whose concepts are developed over a 1-2 week introduction period and that are exemplified and built upon in 3-4, 2-3-week long detailed case studies

● General principles of species-environmental interactions, including definitions and examples of tolerance ranges, fundamental and realised niche, climate envelopes, and effects of stable to highly variable environments.

● Consideration of general timeframes of both environmental changes and animal responses, including geological/evolutionary to ongoing global environmental change, organismal range shifts, expansions, contractions and extinctions.

● Examples of mechanisms and limits of physiological control systems (conformity, regulation, homeostasis) and comparison or integration with phenotypically plastic responses (physiological/biochemical/morphological plasticity), behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses  

● A detailed examination of environmental challenges to animal life, including physical and chemical factors defining and differentiating ecosystems, e.g. latitude and elevation or water depth, oxygen levels (normoxic, hypoxic, anoxic, or hyperoxic), temperature (minimum, maximum and average), water availability, soil or water chemistry and nutrient content.

● Case studies of mechanisms of environmental adaptation

3-4 case studies including different groups of organisms and environments according to teaching staff expertise. Cross cutting themes include for example:

- Diversity of solutions to similar challenges across organisms, e.g. endotherms versus ectotherms; invertebrates versus vertebrates

- Integration of adaptive mechanisms from cellular to whole organism levels

- Relationships between lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation and ability to maintain homeostasis

- Ecological consequences of adaptive processes
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (2 lectures and 1 workshop in each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (Inclusivity). During workshops, students will be encouraged to discuss relevant topics in small groups (active learning, confidence). Students will be encouraged to reflect on local, national and global phenomena, e.g. in relation to climate change (global citizenship).

Lectures:

These will cover the core module content.

Attendance Record: Yes

Workshops:

Structured workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics through active learning. Workshops will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools such as Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two assignments. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a 5-minute explainer video based on topics from the first half of the module. In this assessment, we expect students to produce an informative and engaging video aimed at first year Biosciences students. When writing the script, students are expected to use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. As a formative task, students will have the opportunity to submit a short (30 sec) video to develop their video making skills. Due to the nature of this task, this assessment is not anonymous.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is a final written exam consisting of short answer questions. The questions consist of problem solving tasks and critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. When they address the question, students should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use their understanding of relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis.
Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. In addition, the video assessment resembles a potential ‘real life’ situation that students may encounter in their professional life. The final exam requires students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS222
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments including those characterised by extreme chemical and physical factors such as low or high oxygen levels or temperature. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. Using case studies, the module will explore physiological control systems and phenotypically plastic responses, behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the diversity, time frames and limits of physiological mechanisms that animals employ to survive and thrive in challenging environments.

2. To raise students’ critical awareness of the challenges of interacting abiotic environmental factors encountered by animals in their natural environments.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Outline Syllabus
This module builds on and further develops the principles of species-environmental interactions introduced in Year 1 core modules. There are 4 overarching topics whose concepts are developed over a 1-2 week introduction period and that are exemplified and built upon in 3-4, 2-3-week long detailed case studies

● General principles of species-environmental interactions, including definitions and examples of tolerance ranges, fundamental and realised niche, climate envelopes, and effects of stable to highly variable environments.

● Consideration of general timeframes of both environmental changes and animal responses, including geological/evolutionary to ongoing global environmental change, organismal range shifts, expansions, contractions and extinctions.

● Examples of mechanisms and limits of physiological control systems (conformity, regulation, homeostasis) and comparison or integration with phenotypically plastic responses (physiological/biochemical/morphological plasticity), behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses  

● A detailed examination of environmental challenges to animal life, including physical and chemical factors defining and differentiating ecosystems, e.g. latitude and elevation or water depth, oxygen levels (normoxic, hypoxic, anoxic, or hyperoxic), temperature (minimum, maximum and average), water availability, soil or water chemistry and nutrient content.

● Case studies of mechanisms of environmental adaptation

3-4 case studies including different groups of organisms and environments according to teaching staff expertise. Cross cutting themes include for example:

- Diversity of solutions to similar challenges across organisms, e.g. endotherms versus ectotherms; invertebrates versus vertebrates

- Integration of adaptive mechanisms from cellular to whole organism levels

- Relationships between lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation and ability to maintain homeostasis

- Ecological consequences of adaptive processes
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (2 lectures and 1 workshop in each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (Inclusivity). During workshops, students will be encouraged to discuss relevant topics in small groups (active learning, confidence). Students will be encouraged to reflect on local, national and global phenomena, e.g. in relation to climate change (global citizenship).

Lectures:

These will cover the core module content.

Attendance Record: Yes

Workshops:

Structured workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics through active learning. Workshops will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools such as Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two assignments. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a 5-minute explainer video based on topics from the first half of the module. In this assessment, we expect students to produce an informative and engaging video aimed at first year Biosciences students. When writing the script, students are expected to use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. As a formative task, students will have the opportunity to submit a short (30 sec) video to develop their video making skills. Due to the nature of this task, this assessment is not anonymous.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is a final written exam consisting of short answer questions. The questions consist of problem solving tasks and critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. When they address the question, students should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use their understanding of relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis.
Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. In addition, the video assessment resembles a potential ‘real life’ situation that students may encounter in their professional life. The final exam requires students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Analyse relationships between animal lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation, and ability to maintain homeostasis.
 LO2 Evaluate integrative physiological mechanisms enabling animals to survive in potentially hostile environmental conditions.
 LO3 Critically discuss major transitions in the evolution of animals, e.g. air-breathing, terrestriality, or endothermy.
 LO4 Evaluate and interpret data to solve problems and predict outcomes related to survival of species
Skills

Skills

 S2 Digital skills

 S4 Critical thinking and problem solving

BIOS222
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments including those characterised by extreme chemical and physical factors such as low or high oxygen levels or temperature. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. Using case studies, the module will explore physiological control systems and phenotypically plastic responses, behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the diversity, time frames and limits of physiological mechanisms that animals employ to survive and thrive in challenging environments.

2. To raise students’ critical awareness of the challenges of interacting abiotic environmental factors encountered by animals in their natural environments.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Outline Syllabus
This module builds on and further develops the principles of species-environmental interactions introduced in Year 1 core modules. There are 4 overarching topics whose concepts are developed over a 1-2 week introduction period and that are exemplified and built upon in 3-4, 2-3-week long detailed case studies

● General principles of species-environmental interactions, including definitions and examples of tolerance ranges, fundamental and realised niche, climate envelopes, and effects of stable to highly variable environments.

● Consideration of general timeframes of both environmental changes and animal responses, including geological/evolutionary to ongoing global environmental change, organismal range shifts, expansions, contractions and extinctions.

● Examples of mechanisms and limits of physiological control systems (conformity, regulation, homeostasis) and comparison or integration with phenotypically plastic responses (physiological/biochemical/morphological plasticity), behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses  

● A detailed examination of environmental challenges to animal life, including physical and chemical factors defining and differentiating ecosystems, e.g. latitude and elevation or water depth, oxygen levels (normoxic, hypoxic, anoxic, or hyperoxic), temperature (minimum, maximum and average), water availability, soil or water chemistry and nutrient content.

● Case studies of mechanisms of environmental adaptation

3-4 case studies including different groups of organisms and environments according to teaching staff expertise. Cross cutting themes include for example:

- Diversity of solutions to similar challenges across organisms, e.g. endotherms versus ectotherms; invertebrates versus vertebrates

- Integration of adaptive mechanisms from cellular to whole organism levels

- Relationships between lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation and ability to maintain homeostasis

- Ecological consequences of adaptive processes
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (2 lectures and 1 workshop in each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (Inclusivity). During workshops, students will be encouraged to discuss relevant topics in small groups (active learning, confidence). Students will be encouraged to reflect on local, national and global phenomena, e.g. in relation to climate change (global citizenship).

Lectures:

These will cover the core module content.

Attendance Record: Yes

Workshops:

Structured workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics through active learning. Workshops will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools such as Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two assignments. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a 5-minute explainer video based on topics from the first half of the module. In this assessment, we expect students to produce an informative and engaging video aimed at first year Biosciences students. When writing the script, students are expected to use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. As a formative task, students will have the opportunity to submit a short (30 sec) video to develop their video making skills. Due to the nature of this task, this assessment is not anonymous.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is a final written exam consisting of short answer questions. The questions consist of problem solving tasks and critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. When they address the question, students should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use their understanding of relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis.
Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. In addition, the video assessment resembles a potential ‘real life’ situation that students may encounter in their professional life. The final exam requires students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Analyse relationships between animal lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation, and ability to maintain homeostasis.
 LO2 Evaluate integrative physiological mechanisms enabling animals to survive in potentially hostile environmental conditions.
 LO3 Critically discuss major transitions in the evolution of animals, e.g. air-breathing, terrestriality, or endothermy.
 LO4 Evaluate and interpret data to solve problems and predict outcomes related to survival of species

BIOS222
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments including those characterised by extreme chemical and physical factors such as low or high oxygen levels or temperature. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. Using case studies, the module will explore physiological control systems and phenotypically plastic responses, behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Educational Aims
1. To develop students’ understanding of the diversity, time frames and limits of physiological mechanisms that animals employ to survive and thrive in challenging environments.

2. To raise students’ critical awareness of the challenges of interacting abiotic environmental factors encountered by animals in their natural environments.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is concerned with the question how animals survive in challenging, often hostile environments. It will examine physiological adaptations that occur when animals face changes in their environment, either acute short term changes or over longer periods of time, such as seasonal changes, those over evolutionary time scales, or ongoing climate change. The module is taught through lectures and interactive workshops which will give students the opportunity to discuss concepts and practice problem solving. The assessment consists of producing a short explainer video and a final exam.
Outline Syllabus
This module builds on and further develops the principles of species-environmental interactions introduced in Year 1 core modules. There are 4 overarching topics whose concepts are developed over a 1-2 week introduction period and that are exemplified and built upon in 3-4, 2-3-week long detailed case studies

● General principles of species-environmental interactions, including definitions and examples of tolerance ranges, fundamental and realised niche, climate envelopes, and effects of stable to highly variable environments.

● Consideration of general timeframes of both environmental changes and animal responses, including geological/evolutionary to ongoing global environmental change, organismal range shifts, expansions, contractions and extinctions.

● Examples of mechanisms and limits of physiological control systems (conformity, regulation, homeostasis) and comparison or integration with phenotypically plastic responses (physiological/biochemical/morphological plasticity), behavioural responses, and genetic adaptations in the above responses  

● A detailed examination of environmental challenges to animal life, including physical and chemical factors defining and differentiating ecosystems, e.g. latitude and elevation or water depth, oxygen levels (normoxic, hypoxic, anoxic, or hyperoxic), temperature (minimum, maximum and average), water availability, soil or water chemistry and nutrient content.

● Case studies of mechanisms of environmental adaptation

3-4 case studies including different groups of organisms and environments according to teaching staff expertise. Cross cutting themes include for example:

- Diversity of solutions to similar challenges across organisms, e.g. endotherms versus ectotherms; invertebrates versus vertebrates

- Integration of adaptive mechanisms from cellular to whole organism levels

- Relationships between lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation and ability to maintain homeostasis

- Ecological consequences of adaptive processes
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module will be taught via a mixture of lectures and workshops (2 lectures and 1 workshop in each week). Learning and teaching throughout this module is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching). Students will have access to online materials including discussion boards, videos, slides and websites (digital literacy). Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access the material remotely (Inclusivity). During workshops, students will be encouraged to discuss relevant topics in small groups (active learning, confidence). Students will be encouraged to reflect on local, national and global phenomena, e.g. in relation to climate change (global citizenship).

Lectures:

These will cover the core module content.

Attendance Record: Yes

Workshops:

Structured workshops will be used to deepen students’ understanding of the topics through active learning. Workshops will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools such as Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
This module will be assessed by two assignments. The first assessment (worth 40% of the module) is a 5-minute explainer video based on topics from the first half of the module. In this assessment, we expect students to produce an informative and engaging video aimed at first year Biosciences students. When writing the script, students are expected to use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. As a formative task, students will have the opportunity to submit a short (30 sec) video to develop their video making skills. Due to the nature of this task, this assessment is not anonymous.

The second assessment (worth 60%) is a final written exam consisting of short answer questions. The questions consist of problem solving tasks and critical interpretation of data related to the presented case studies. When they address the question, students should use their knowledge and understanding of the module content, but they should also use their understanding of relevant literature to add a different perspective and/or more detail. At the higher end of the marking scheme, markers will also be looking for an element of criticality and synthesis.
Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. In addition, the video assessment resembles a potential ‘real life’ situation that students may encounter in their professional life. The final exam requires students to apply problem solving skills which are expected by many employers of our graduates.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Analyse relationships between animal lifestyle, increasing complexity of bodily organisation, and ability to maintain homeostasis.
 LO2 Evaluate integrative physiological mechanisms enabling animals to survive in potentially hostile environmental conditions.
 LO3 Critically discuss major transitions in the evolution of animals, e.g. air-breathing, terrestriality, or endothermy.
 LO4 Evaluate and interpret data to solve problems and predict outcomes related to survival of species
